All young animals naturally delight to be
in the open air, and in perpetual motion; but
we signify our dsapprobation of this inten-
ton Of nature, by confirming our infants most
" in houses, and swath.ug them, when born,
as tightly as possible. This natural instinct
appears very strong, when we see child
released from its confinement in the short in
terval betwixt pulling off its day clothes, and
swathng it again before it is put to sleep
The evident tokens of delight which the lit
tie creature shows in recovering the free use
of its limbs, and the strong reluctance 1t dis
covers to be again remitted to its bondage.
one would think should strike conviction OF
the cruelty and absurtlity Of this practice in.
into the most stupid of mankind.-Er. Gre
cory.

When nature had created the lovely rose,
the spirit of the rose bush said to the guar
dian angel Of the flowers, will you leave the
noble plant without single defence, to pro-
tect it against rude assaults? Has not ma
ture armed even the hawthorn with strong
and sharp points? The hawthorn, replied
the angel, belongs not to the mobiles, but the
menials Of creation. 1t is his destiny to pro-
tect the tender plants against brutes-tor
that purpose nature gave him sharp thorns.
However, thy wish be granted. 80 said the
angel, and armed the rose bush with delicate
stings. Of what use are such slender weap,-.
ons? replied the spirit OF the rose, they VIII
not protect the beautiful Hover. But the
angel answered him--Ihey are intended to
keen off the unreAecting hand Of children
THE PROTECTION.
a parable from tie German Of Krumn'ac

By apolying good microscope to the
skin ofthe human body multitude OF small
pores will be seen, through which perspi-
ration is continually issuing. 1t is calculated
there are million OF these pores in every
square inch, and 2,0l6, 100000 in the whole
body Of middle sized person.-Ihe naked
body, exposed to the rays of a burning sun,
appears through microscope to be surround-
ed with cloud of steam. Let any person
hold the tip of the finger at the distance ot
the twelfth part of an inch from looking
glass, and the surface Of the glass will soon
become dmmed by the matter issuing from
the finger.


Many experiments have been made to as
certain the quantity of perspirable matter
which is emitted from the skin. 1t is stated
in the n. E. Encyciopcdia that Mr. Crnick-
shanks put his hand into a glass vessel closed
at the wrist, and by keeping it there an hour
he collected thirty grains of liquid which
had issued through the pores Of the skin.--
On repeating the experiment in the even
ing, he collected twelve grains. The mean
of these is 81 grains. Taking p grains per
hour, and supposng the hand to be one-s,X-
tieth part of the surface of the body, the
pcrspiration IN "a hours would amount to 5
pounds ounces troy. Sanctolous says
FIVE -cighths of all the aliment Good and
drink received by the mouth is carried OH
by pcrspiration. Dodart says seven eighths
Others estimate it at much less, making II
about two pounds per day. The quantity
of sweat or perspirabic matter varies ac-
cording to the climate, season OF the year,
age. sex, state of the health, &c.


It is by the peculiar smell which the
substance emitted from the skin gives tc
each individual, that the dog can discov-
err his mas.er, and even trace him to a dis
tanCe.

we had full view Of nearly the whole pop
ulation in bed: many we're asleep; some few

MopE OF DIsPER,ING GocusTs.-We
trayersed the grand st.ppe or desert OF AS
trakhan for two days. On the evening OF
the first Of August, W, arrived at a Russian
village which was surrounded by a consider
able tract OF we'll cultivated land. While
changing horses, / witnessed what to me
was a very curious signt--a vast flight OF To-
Gusts. extending fifteen miles, suddenly
made their appearance from the east, and
came in a huge phals,x to attack the crops.
Tn an instant every villager was on the road
to his own field. Some took dogs, others
were on horseback, and others ran shouting
and clapping their hands all the way, the in
habitants finding from experience that the
locusts very much dislike noise. My fellow
traveller told me that in the colony OF l&arass,
when the locustf came in sight, rot only all
the inhabitants, but the military turn out,
and endeavor to drive them off, by drums
and flies, and apsrpetual discharge OF mus
kerry. The enemy, thus repulsed, make
speedy retreat, and commit their depreda-
4 dations on tho lands of these who are less on
/ the alert to receive them.


/ A RUSSIAN ATAzoN.--On dismounting al
village near Dirkee, my stiriup WIS held
/ bv a fair and handsome looking person, whc
proved to be a enale. Admiration OF q mil
itary life had Induced her to deprive hersel
of her fair trcses, and to wear the dress e
man, preparatory, as she SAID, to Offer
ing her services 70 the Emperor as sol
der Hearin, that was on the way, she
told me that f she had been little older,
she would haze accompanied me. Itold her
that she woud be rejected from her femi-
nine appearance, but SHE said she would cut
off her breasts whenever they were too large
for conceament. On taking leave of this lit
tie amazo gave her an old aiguillcttc,
which sheaceepted with great delight, and
strutted If with it on her shoulder, TO the

During the recent expedition of Moham-
med Ali Pasha, the vceroy of Egypt, against
the Wahabecs of the Hedjaz, his highness
was detained in the Holy Land OF Mahom-
medans much longer period than he anti
cipated on his Setting out for the war. Nei-
ther the tomb Of the Prophet at Medina, nor
the temple Of the faithful at Mecca, could
console him for the loss of his harem, which
he had left behind him at the Egyptian cap
ital, in the hope Of his speedy return to the
place in which they were immuTed. he had
accordingly sent off expresses by the ncetcst
dromcdaries commanding the whole OF his
wives and attendants to be brought to him;
and large caravan being about to be form
ed, for the purpose accompanying ana con.
veying them ON their route, avalled myself
of this favorable opportunity to cross tna
Desert of Suez under its protectlon; and al
ter the usual preparation tor such journey,
encamped with the rest, on the banks of
Bukctcl- Hail, or the Lake of the Pilgrims,
few miles from Cairo, which forms the
GRAND rendezvous at which all the scattered
clements of the caravans are finally united,
and from whence they set out i'll the order
necessary for their security. At noon the
first signal gun for loading was fired, when
all was hustle and confusion; aud the break
ing up of the tents, harnessing the animals
to the clumsy carriages, constructed for the
conveyance of the Pasha's wives and princi-
pal slaves, loading the camels which had all
been watered at the lake in the morning. ar
ranging the stations of the Turkish cavalry
as guards, &c. occupied all parties until
nearly four O'Clock in the afternoon.


At length, on the firing of secohd gun,
the whole caravan was put in motion, and
commenced its march in the following Dr.

OUR OWN FIRE SIDE.
Dear in morn's soft blowing gale


Is budding May;
Sweet in the wild-rosc scented vale
The scattered hay;
Dear is the carly evening star,


The lovers guide;
But dearcr still, and sweeter far,


Our own freside.
Dear is the linnet's lively song,


That cheers the grove;
Sweet is the breeze that watts along
The sigh Of love;
Dear to the sailors heart the call


Of land deserted,
But, all more dear, more sweet than all,
Our own fireside.

TIE FAMILY BIBLE.
How painfully pleasing the fond recollection
OF Youthful connexions and innocent JOY,
When blest with parental advice and affection,
Surrounded with mercies-with peace from on


high;
still view the chairs of my sire and my mother,
The seats of their offspring as ranged on each


hand;
And that richest of books, that exccll'd every O.


ther,
The Family Biblc, which lay on the stand.
The old fashioned bible, the dear blessed bible,
The family bible which lay on the stand.
That bible, the volume of Gods inspiration,
At morn and at evening would yield us de-


light;
And the prayer of our sire was sweet invocation
For mercy by day, and safety through night.
Our hymns of thanksgiving with harmony swell


ing,


All warm from the hearts of a family band,
Half raised us from earth to that rapturous dwell


ing,


Descrb'd in the bible that lay on the stand.
The old fashioned bible, the dear blessed bible,
The family bible WHICH lay on the stand
Ye scenes Of tranquility, long have we parted,
My hopes almost gone, and my parents no


more;


In sorrow and sadness live broken hearted,
And wander unknown on a far distant shore
Yet how can doubt dear Saviours protection
Forgetful of gifs from his bountiful hand;
Oh let me with patience receive his correction,
And think on the bible that lay on the stand.
The old fashioned bible, the dear blessed bible,
The family bible that lay on the stand.

TIE FAMILY BIBLE

ssImmortal Hope,


Takes comfort from the foaming billow's rage
And makesa welcome harbor 20 the tomb"


There is, perhaps. (says an eloquent wri-
ter of the present day. no feeling which the
human breast cherishes, so nearly connected
with its happiness as Hope. And it was
mercifuIly appointed that in world, whose
brightest visions of felicity prove but the
shadow Of q shade--whosc past pleasures,
while they feast the memory, leave the
heart aching with sense of their desertion,
and whose present enjoyments vanish ere
they are graspcd, and wlther ere they bloom
some more endni ing realities should be held
out to the anticipation OF the spirit, iainting
under wearincss and disappointment. When
sin entered the bowers of Eden, and the pri-
mary curse had been pronounced ON the
parents of the human race, HOPE, the young
and beautiful offspring of untaintcd joys, So
iourned with the exiles, and attended on
their wanderings She cheered them with
the song of future and happier days, pointed
them to the horizon Of eternal life, and show
ed the first glimmerings of that bright and
morning star, which should rise on Beth
lehem and set on Calvary, but whose bright
ness should remain, and whose memory
should live, till eternity had lost itself in its





and thorny path, and partaken deeply of
the wretchedness Of the world, which she
came to solace aud to cheer. Time was when
she could have flown over the distractions
of her path, but the cruelty of men has
bound her wings, and her feet have bled a.
/ mong the briars of the wilderness.


1t has been the Christian bosom which has
cherished best this worn and wandering pill
griul--while the pilgrim, in her turn. has
warmed and cheered the bosom that gave
her shelter And while Hope has listened
to the tale of sorrows, which the suffering
children of humanity have poured into her
ear. her eye has kndled with the brightness
of immortality, her voice has tremblcd with
the inspiration of prophecy, and she has
infused into their "song in the house OF their
lpigrimage,' the JOY and peace OF believ-
ing, and the assurance Of eternal salvation.

molestation, the Indians probably being a.
ware, that little if anything could be obtain-
ed from him, and fearing that an attack up
on him would lead to immediate detection
and pursuit. On the third day he observed
that the bushes around the log were appa-
rently dying, and being unable to conjecture
the cause, was attracted by curiosity to-
wards the spot, and had advanced to within
about ten feet, for the purpose of ascertain
ing what was the matter, when his atten~
tion was caught by the auttering of a beauti-
full bird, entangled in some burs just by him.
He instantly turned and caught the bird,
which drew of his curiosity about the dying
bushes, and he returned to the fort and
spent the remainder of the day in making q
cage for his bird. Had he not been inter-
rupted, he would instantly have been taken
by the Indians without the firing of single
gun. So completely were his thoughts occu-
pied with his little bird, that he forgot to
mention the circumstance OF the dying BUSH
es. The next morning early, pack-horse
driver and his son went out to see after their
horses when the concealed Indians shot
them both, scalped and stripped them before
the people of the fort who heard the guns,
could get to the place. They having pre-
viousy stolen and secured number OF hors-
es, they instantly made off.


One Sunday morning three men, one by
the name OF Poor, another named Wade,
the name of the third not recollected, who
had been in the habit of accommodating the
country in the capacity OF spies, proposed
to Mr.. Downing to so with them to Mud
Lick, now the Olympian Springs, seven
miles distant from the fort. They accord


ngly set out together on foot, and travelled
unmolested until they came i'll sight of the
Lck.-As they ascended hill, they dicov-
cred several hundred buffaloes, elks and
deer, which they considered an indication
that there were no Indians there; but whilst
they were surveying the prospects and were
descending the hill, Poor and Wade, who
were some distance in advance OF Downing
and his companion, suddenly turned round
and gave notice that there were ten or tt-
teen Indians sitting and endeavoring to con-
ceal themselves in the drain that proceeded
! from the Lick, and that it was necessary
that thev should ny for their lives. They
Immediately tarted and ran with all possi-
BILE speed, but soon heard the Indians behind
them. The pursued took one path and the
pursuers took another, but after short dis
tance the two paths came together-the
whites however, reached the point of junction
before the Indians, although the latter gain
ed the choice of paths. Young Downing be-
| iilH Sthdll, duu hoi ihC mo w" "PobA0hS az


customed to running, was unable to keep up
with them, and was advised as the only
chance of escape, to embrace the first oP-
portunity when the situation of the road
should throw them out of sight of the Indi-
ans, to step behind log and lie concealed
whilst the rest OF the party ran on. Reluct-
ant as he felt to be left in the woods sur
rounded by savages, he considered it the on
| ly alternative, and followed the advice.-Ac-
corlingly the first opportunity that present.
ed itself, he jumped aside from the path, and
lay close behind log. The Indians soon
came along, and eagre in the pursuit to over
take those whom they still saw before them,
passed by Downing who lay trembling by the
way side. About ten minutes after they
PASSED, he ventured to raise and leave his
place of concealment-for some time how
ever, he was utterly at loss what course
to pursue. To go back towards the Lick


was his first thought. but it was abandoned
almost as soon as conceived. In this state
of uncertainty, he slowly walked along the
path in the direction the Indians had taken.


A little reflection, however, convinced him
of the danger of this course; as it was very
probable they would soon turn and come the
same direction back-he therefore left the
path, and, after wandering through the
woods, reached the fort in safety, several
hours after his companions, who had outrun
their pursuers and returned likwise.

Whatever is sacred, or beautiful, carries
its own protection with it, and nature sur
rounds it with but slight defence, which
warns but wounds not-for with beauty,
mildness alone should be united. Thus to
innocence, nature gave modcsty blush.

From Keepers Journey from india 10 England


MoRAvIAN EsTABLrsHMENT.-I went
to visit Moravian Establish mcnt in the
town of Sarapta. Opposite the Inn former
ly stood house containing eighty bachelors,
and near it one containing eighty spinsters
The house of the former has been burnt
down; and that of the latter has escaped
The females divide their own dwelling with
the men, till theirs is rebuilt. When bach
elor is tired of life Of celbacy, he goes
next door, chooses one out OF the eighty SPIN
sters, and makes her his wife. The pair be-
come members of the general community,
and keep house for themselves. The va
cancies are filled up by the children OF those
who had once been inmates OF these mansions
of single blessedness. was highly gratificd
with my visit to this human hive. Every
thing was in the neatest order; the sisters,
as they are called, with their little caps and
uniform dress, reminded me of our fair Qua
kers The female children were reading
and writing; the young women were engaged
in domestic employ ments. The old maids,
were occupied in knitting and needle
work. All were busy at the occupation
best adapted to their peculiar habits and
talents Nor were the brothers idle; here
were shoemakers, tailors, weavers, printers
and book binders. / was shown tne col
lection of the serpents and other reptiles OF
Southern Russia. saw also large coilec-
ton of antiquities found in the neighborhood'
which proves the former existence OF an an
cient city ON this spot


Curious ExHIBITIoN.-On entering
Nnana. we were witnesses to rather Gu
rious exhibition. / should first mention, that
the Persians are in the habit OF sleeping on
f1at roofs of their houses, during the sum-
.mer months. Day was just breaking as we
arrived. AS the houses of the poor classes
are generally not more than eight feet high,
From Keppcrs Journey from India to Engla

In the month of August 1886, Mr.. Francis
Downing then lad lived in fort, where
soon afterwards, an Ironworks was erected
by Mr.. Jacob Myers, which is known as
the Slate cpeek works. and owned by Col.
Thomas Dye Owings. 4


One morning young man by the name OF
Yates, together with Mr.. Downing, went out
in search q horse that had strayed away
from the fort. After travelling six or eight
miles in search of the horse, Downing be-
gan 10 be alarmed at the idea of danger
from Indians, and observed to Yates, (who
was much older than himself, and to whom
he locked Up for protection) that he thought
he heard noise like sticks cracking behind
them, Yates laughed at him anc told him
not to be a coward--tMat it was oHly his I'M
agnetiun, and that there was no danger
whatever. Downing, however, was not
convinced, but embraced the first favorable
opportunity tIfordcd him for conccalnent,
to step in a thick cluster Of whortclberry
bushes, while Yates went on. ln few
minutes an Indian was seen by Downing,
running towards him, until he was within a
bout one hundred yards, when he suddenly
stopped. Downing to use his own express
| ion, was as it were, Mtnder&trnck. He re-
solved however, as he had gun, to fire and
run, but unfortunately his gun having
double trigger, before he raised her to his
face, she went off, and, as he remarks, ne IN
stantly 7vent oftoo! After running some
distance, he met Yates, who having heard
the report of the gun, had turned to ascer-
tain what was the matter, and learning that
thev were closely pursued by Indians, they
ran together At length they reached de-
clivity, and we're compelled, in following the
path, to de scend into valley surrounded by
VILLA Iar fhav Indians. who
| had taken shorter route, and were running
| by another route towards the bottom OF the
! v lley There was no alternative; It was
absolutely necessary to keep the path and
to run with the utmost possible rapidity, al
though from the superior knowledge possess
ed by the Indians ofdfferent roads. they had
gained considerably on the pursued, and
seemed likely soon to overtake them. Both
parties ran on until they reached dry gut
ter in the middle of the valley. about six
feet deep, and Of considerable width. The
| Indians had, by this time approached very
near them, and attempted to leap across the
gutter at about the same time With the
whites. All got across safe except Mt u.
who Just reached the edge OF the gutter, "a
gainst which striking his foot, he fell upon
his breas, rebounded and fell backwards in-
to the gutter. The violence OF the fail al
most deprived him Of breath tor time, but
fortunately the Indians were too intent upon
the chase to observe his remaining behind,
and both happening to direct their attention
solely to MIR. Yates, continued to pursue
hin. Mr.. Downing at length recovering
from the shock, walked along IN the gutter,
which grew shalower as he advanced, and
soon ceased to serve the purpose OF conceal
ing him from the sight OF the lniians. At
length he discovered one of them returning
in search of him he instantly dropped his
gun. left the gutter, and ran back the same


wav he had come.--The injury he had re-
ceived from his fall, affected his speed, and
the Inlian gained upon him rapidly. After
running a considerable distance, considering
his case a desperate ono, and his being over
taken inevitable, he came to large poplar


tree, which had been blown down by. the


wind, II so happened that wh'lstHhe ran a.
long one side of the tree, the lndian pursued


him on the other. At this critical momcnt,


he felt himself caught by the leg, ana was


compelled to make momentary pause,


when he perceived that he had been stop"


ped by a small dog, which instantly ran q


way from him. This pause mac gwen 10
the Indian considerable advantage, and he


percejyed himself likely TO be caught at


the root of the tree. Mos' fortunately how


ever lust at that spot, a large she bear had


taken up her abode with several cubs. Not


being pleased with the violence with Which


the Indian approached her young, she IN


stantly attacked him, when Mr. Downing,
taking advantage of the interference OF TINS
unexpected coadjutor, suddenly wheeled
around, and left the savage engaged IN


most violent struggle with his new adversa-
nv. What was the result of the rencounter,


we are not informed. 1t had, however, the
happy effect of preserving Mr.. Downing
from almost inevitable destruction; and as
no remains of the Indian was ever alter


wards found, at or near the place, it is prop


able he escaped with his life, it not without
considerable injury.


Mr.. Yates likewise succeeded in getting
off unhurt. After running several miles, he
concealed himself amidst trees or in Cane
Drake, and he thus eluded the pursuit, and


returned home safe.


1t was custom with Mr. Downing, i'll the


summer, about the time referred to above,


to go out of the fort every afternoon, to


cluster OF hickory trees, several hundrea


yards distant, for the purpose OF shooting


squirrels, which at that place were very hu


merous.-Near his path, (as he afterwards


s:scovered) fifteen Indians lay concealed tor
three davs, behind large log, where they


had placed a number of bushes to serve as a
blind. there waiting for a favorable oppor-


tuntv to kill some one or more men, and Oh
tain y,luuder

ny eating; and it fears to starve unless
1t still may feed and all it sees devour
Ambition is not tir'd with toll, nor cloy'd with


pow'r.
AMBITION.

full articles.headline: 4 HINT TO MOTHERS.
full articles.article:
All young animals naturally delight to be
in the open air, and in perpetual motion; but
we signify our dsapprobation of this inten-
ton Of nature, by confirming our infants most
" in houses, and swath.ug them, when born,
as tightly as possible. This natural instinct
appears very strong, when we see child
released from its confinement in the short in
terval betwixt pulling off its day clothes, and
swathng it again before it is put to sleep
The evident tokens of delight which the lit
tie creature shows in recovering the free use
of its limbs, and the strong reluctance 1t dis
covers to be again remitted to its bondage.
one would think should strike conviction OF
the cruelty and absurtlity Of this practice in.
into the most stupid of mankind.-Er. Gre
cory.

full articles.headline: THE PROTECTION.
full articles.article:
a paraJle from tie German Of Krummacaer.


When nature had created the lovely rose,
the spirit of the rose bush said to the guar
dian angel Of the flowers, will you leave the
noble plant without single defence, to pro-
tect it against rude assaults? Has not ma
ture armed even the hawthorn with strong
and sharp points? The hawthorn, replied
the angel, belongs not to the mobiles, but the
menials Of creation. 1t is his destiny to pro-
tect the tender plants against brutes-tor
that purpose nature gave him sharp thorns.
However, thy wish be granted. 80 said the
angel, and armed the rose bush with delicate
stings. Of what use are such slender weap,-.
ons? replied the spirit OF the rose, they VIII
not protect the beautiful Hover. But the
angel answered him--Ihey are intended to
keen off the unreAecting hand Of children
full articles.byline: a parable from tie German Of Krumn'ac

full articles.headline: PORES OF THE HUMAN BODY.
full articles.article:
By apolying good microscope to the
skin ofthe human body multitude OF small
pores will be seen, through which perspi-
ration is continually issuing. 1t is calculated
there are million OF these pores in every
square inch, and 2,0l6, 100000 in the whole
body Of middle sized person.-Ihe naked
body, exposed to the rays of a burning sun,
appears through microscope to be surround-
ed with cloud of steam. Let any person
hold the tip of the finger at the distance ot
the twelfth part of an inch from looking
glass, and the surface Of the glass will soon
become dmmed by the matter issuing from
the finger.


Many experiments have been made to as
certain the quantity of perspirable matter
which is emitted from the skin. 1t is stated
in the n. E. Encyciopcdia that Mr. Crnick-
shanks put his hand into a glass vessel closed
at the wrist, and by keeping it there an hour
he collected thirty grains of liquid which
had issued through the pores Of the skin.--
On repeating the experiment in the even
ing, he collected twelve grains. The mean
of these is 81 grains. Taking p grains per
hour, and supposng the hand to be one-s,X-
tieth part of the surface of the body, the
pcrspiration IN "a hours would amount to 5
pounds ounces troy. Sanctolous says
FIVE -cighths of all the aliment Good and
drink received by the mouth is carried OH
by pcrspiration. Dodart says seven eighths
Others estimate it at much less, making II
about two pounds per day. The quantity
of sweat or perspirabic matter varies ac-
cording to the climate, season OF the year,
age. sex, state of the health, &c.


It is by the peculiar smell which the
substance emitted from the skin gives tc
each individual, that the dog can discov-
err his mas.er, and even trace him to a dis
tanCe.

we had full view Of nearly the whole pop
ulation in bed: many we're asleep; some few
had awoke; others we're getting out OF bed,
to make their morning toilettcs. The scene
was highly entertaining, and brought to mind
the story of Lc Dil5le Boiteux, unroof
ing the houses for the qualification Of Don
Cleofas.


MopE OF DIsPER,ING GocusTs.-We
trayersed the grand st.ppe or desert OF AS
trakhan for two days. On the evening OF
the first Of August, W, arrived at a Russian
village which was surrounded by a consider
able tract OF we'll cultivated land. While
changing horses, / witnessed what to me
was a very curious signt--a vast flight OF To-
Gusts. extending fifteen miles, suddenly
made their appearance from the east, and
came in a huge phals,x to attack the crops.
Tn an instant every villager was on the road
to his own field. Some took dogs, others
were on horseback, and others ran shouting
and clapping their hands all the way, the in
habitants finding from experience that the
locusts very much dislike noise. My fellow
traveller told me that in the colony OF l&arass,
when the locustf came in sight, rot only all
the inhabitants, but the military turn out,
and endeavor to drive them off, by drums
and flies, and apsrpetual discharge OF mus
kerry. The enemy, thus repulsed, make
speedy retreat, and commit their depreda-
4 dations on tho lands of these who are less on
/ the alert to receive them.


/ A RUSSIAN ATAzoN.--On dismounting al
village near Dirkee, my stiriup WIS held
/ bv a fair and handsome looking person, whc
proved to be a enale. Admiration OF q mil
itary life had Induced her to deprive hersel
of her fair trcses, and to wear the dress e
man, preparatory, as she SAID, to Offer
ing her services 70 the Emperor as sol
der Hearin, that was on the way, she
told me that f she had been little older,
she would haze accompanied me. Itold her
that she woud be rejected from her femi-
nine appearance, but SHE said she would cut
off her breasts whenever they were too large
for conceament. On taking leave of this lit
tie amazo gave her an old aiguillcttc,
which sheaceepted with great delight, and
strutted If with it on her shoulder, TO the
TO small .ma2ement of the villagers

be biased either by interest, fear resentment, or
affection, to deviate from truth, which is the
mother Of history, the prcseryer and eternlzcr
of great actions, the professed enemy OF obivi-
on, the witness Of things past, and the director
of future times,


ApoLosr.-A Young man having broken an APP
pointment with DIR. Franklin came to him the
following day and made very handsome apollo
g, for his absence. He was proceeding when
the Doctor stopped him, with ''my good boy,
say no more, you have said too much already;
for the man who is so go1d at making an excuse,
is seldom good af any thing else"


CRITICISM Just criticism is more welcome
to true philosopher, than the highest seasoned
praise the former promotes TRUTH the latter pre-
judicesit.


STATugs.--Cato the censor, used to say to
such as expressed their surprise, that SO many
obscure persons of no merit at all, should have
statues, and he should have none: 81 had rather
it should be asked, why no statue has been G.
rcctcd to Cato, than why there has"


pl,ttrarca's Lires.
SIS-1f YOU would be free from sin, fly temp
tation he that docs not endeavor TO aviod the
one cannot expect Providence to protect him
from the other. II the first sparks of i'll were
cuenchcd there would be no fame, for how car
lie kill who tsres not be angry, or be an adultef
CT IN act who does not transgrcss in thought; how
can he be perjured that fears All oath; who dc.
fraud that does not allow himself to coyct.


trainers .fphorisms.
PRAYEn.--Prayer ofall the means Of religion
hath most of the end. 1t exercises our depend
encc upon God, our alteration and praise OF him
and our charity TO men,

full articles.headline:
THE CARAVAN IN THE DESERT.
a Scene, from an unpublished Journal.
full articles.article:
During the recent expedition of Moham-
med Ali Pasha, the vceroy of Egypt, against
the Wahabecs of the Hedjaz, his highness
was detained in the Holy Land OF Mahom-
medans much longer period than he anti
cipated on his Setting out for the war. Nei-
ther the tomb Of the Prophet at Medina, nor
the temple Of the faithful at Mecca, could
console him for the loss of his harem, which
he had left behind him at the Egyptian cap
ital, in the hope Of his speedy return to the
place in which they were immuTed. he had
accordingly sent off expresses by the ncetcst
dromcdaries commanding the whole OF his
wives and attendants to be brought to him;
and large caravan being about to be form
ed, for the purpose accompanying ana con.
veying them ON their route, avalled myself
of this favorable opportunity to cross tna
Desert of Suez under its protectlon; and al
ter the usual preparation tor such journey,
encamped with the rest, on the banks of
Bukctcl- Hail, or the Lake of the Pilgrims,
few miles from Cairo, which forms the
GRAND rendezvous at which all the scattered
clements of the caravans are finally united,
and from whence they set out i'll the order
necessary for their security. At noon the
first signal gun for loading was fired, when
all was hustle and confusion; aud the break
ing up of the tents, harnessing the animals
to the clumsy carriages, constructed for the
conveyance of the Pasha's wives and princi-
pal slaves, loading the camels which had all
been watered at the lake in the morning. ar
ranging the stations of the Turkish cavalry
as guards, &c. occupied all parties until
nearly four O'Clock in the afternoon.


At length, on the firing of secohd gun,
the whole caravan was put in motion, and
commenced its march in the following Dr.

full articles.headline: pe1zE.!7jlc,z.ERgassya I, z.Egass )
full articles.article:
OUR OWN FIRE SIDE.
Dear in morn's soft blowing gale


Is budding May;
Sweet in the wild-rosc scented vale
The scattered hay;
Dear is the carly evening star,


The lovers guide;
But dearcr still, and sweeter far,


Our own freside.
Dear is the linnet's lively song,


That cheers the grove;
Sweet is the breeze that watts along
The sigh Of love;
Dear to the sailors heart the call


Of land deserted,
But, all more dear, more sweet than all,
Our own fireside.

full articles.headline:
From the Charleston Courier.
oh hat I Itpere az in months past JON 29, 2.
TIE FAMILY BIBLE
full articles.article:
oh hat Imeye as in months past. 90, 2.


TIE FAMILY BIBLE.
How painfully pleasing the fond recollection
OF Youthful connexions and innocent JOY,
When blest with parental advice and affection,
Surrounded with mercies-with peace from on


high;
still view the chairs of my sire and my mother,
The seats of their offspring as ranged on each


hand;
And that richest of books, that exccll'd every O.


ther,
The Family Biblc, which lay on the stand.
The old fashioned bible, the dear blessed bible,
The family bible which lay on the stand.
That bible, the volume of Gods inspiration,
At morn and at evening would yield us de-


light;
And the prayer of our sire was sweet invocation
For mercy by day, and safety through night.
Our hymns of thanksgiving with harmony swell


ing,


All warm from the hearts of a family band,
Half raised us from earth to that rapturous dwell


ing,


Descrb'd in the bible that lay on the stand.
The old fashioned bible, the dear blessed bible,
The family bible WHICH lay on the stand
Ye scenes Of tranquility, long have we parted,
My hopes almost gone, and my parents no


more;


In sorrow and sadness live broken hearted,
And wander unknown on a far distant shore
Yet how can doubt dear Saviours protection
Forgetful of gifs from his bountiful hand;
Oh let me with patience receive his correction,
And think on the bible that lay on the stand.
The old fashioned bible, the dear blessed bible,
The family bible that lay on the stand.

full articles.headline:
THE xMDNIIUEs

HOPE.--AN EXTRACT.
full articles.article:
ssImmortal Hope,


Takes comfort from the foaming billow's rage
And makesa welcome harbor 20 the tomb"


There is, perhaps. (says an eloquent wri-
ter of the present day. no feeling which the
human breast cherishes, so nearly connected
with its happiness as Hope. And it was
mercifuIly appointed that in world, whose
brightest visions of felicity prove but the
shadow Of q shade--whosc past pleasures,
while they feast the memory, leave the
heart aching with sense of their desertion,
and whose present enjoyments vanish ere
they are graspcd, and wlther ere they bloom
some more endni ing realities should be held
out to the anticipation OF the spirit, iainting
under wearincss and disappointment. When
sin entered the bowers of Eden, and the pri-
mary curse had been pronounced ON the
parents of the human race, HOPE, the young
and beautiful offspring of untaintcd joys, So
iourned with the exiles, and attended on
their wanderings She cheered them with
the song of future and happier days, pointed
them to the horizon Of eternal life, and show
ed the first glimmerings of that bright and
morning star, which should rise on Beth
lehem and set on Calvary, but whose bright
ness should remain, and whose memory
should live, till eternity had lost itself in its





and thorny path, and partaken deeply of
the wretchedness Of the world, which she
came to solace aud to cheer. Time was when
she could have flown over the distractions
of her path, but the cruelty of men has
bound her wings, and her feet have bled a.
/ mong the briars of the wilderness.


1t has been the Christian bosom which has
cherished best this worn and wandering pill
griul--while the pilgrim, in her turn. has
warmed and cheered the bosom that gave
her shelter And while Hope has listened
to the tale of sorrows, which the suffering
children of humanity have poured into her
ear. her eye has kndled with the brightness
of immortality, her voice has tremblcd with
the inspiration of prophecy, and she has
infused into their "song in the house OF their
lpigrimage,' the JOY and peace OF believ-
ing, and the assurance Of eternal salvation.

molestation, the Indians probably being a.
ware, that little if anything could be obtain-
ed from him, and fearing that an attack up
on him would lead to immediate detection
and pursuit. On the third day he observed
that the bushes around the log were appa-
rently dying, and being unable to conjecture
the cause, was attracted by curiosity to-
wards the spot, and had advanced to within
about ten feet, for the purpose of ascertain
ing what was the matter, when his atten~
tion was caught by the auttering of a beauti-
full bird, entangled in some burs just by him.
He instantly turned and caught the bird,
which drew of his curiosity about the dying
bushes, and he returned to the fort and
spent the remainder of the day in making q
cage for his bird. Had he not been inter-
rupted, he would instantly have been taken
by the Indians without the firing of single
gun. So completely were his thoughts occu-
pied with his little bird, that he forgot to
mention the circumstance OF the dying BUSH
es. The next morning early, pack-horse
driver and his son went out to see after their
horses when the concealed Indians shot
them both, scalped and stripped them before
the people of the fort who heard the guns,
could get to the place. They having pre-
viousy stolen and secured number OF hors-
es, they instantly made off.


One Sunday morning three men, one by
the name OF Poor, another named Wade,
the name of the third not recollected, who
had been in the habit of accommodating the
country in the capacity OF spies, proposed
to Mr.. Downing to so with them to Mud
Lick, now the Olympian Springs, seven
miles distant from the fort. They accord


ngly set out together on foot, and travelled
unmolested until they came i'll sight of the
Lck.-As they ascended hill, they dicov-
cred several hundred buffaloes, elks and
deer, which they considered an indication
that there were no Indians there; but whilst
they were surveying the prospects and were
descending the hill, Poor and Wade, who
were some distance in advance OF Downing
and his companion, suddenly turned round
and gave notice that there were ten or tt-
teen Indians sitting and endeavoring to con-
ceal themselves in the drain that proceeded
! from the Lick, and that it was necessary
that thev should ny for their lives. They
Immediately tarted and ran with all possi-
BILE speed, but soon heard the Indians behind
them. The pursued took one path and the
pursuers took another, but after short dis
tance the two paths came together-the
whites however, reached the point of junction
before the Indians, although the latter gain
ed the choice of paths. Young Downing be-
| iilH Sthdll, duu hoi ihC mo w" "PobA0hS az


customed to running, was unable to keep up
with them, and was advised as the only
chance of escape, to embrace the first oP-
portunity when the situation of the road
should throw them out of sight of the Indi-
ans, to step behind log and lie concealed
whilst the rest OF the party ran on. Reluct-
ant as he felt to be left in the woods sur
rounded by savages, he considered it the on
| ly alternative, and followed the advice.-Ac-
corlingly the first opportunity that present.
ed itself, he jumped aside from the path, and
lay close behind log. The Indians soon
came along, and eagre in the pursuit to over
take those whom they still saw before them,
passed by Downing who lay trembling by the
way side. About ten minutes after they
PASSED, he ventured to raise and leave his
place of concealment-for some time how
ever, he was utterly at loss what course
to pursue. To go back towards the Lick


was his first thought. but it was abandoned
almost as soon as conceived. In this state
of uncertainty, he slowly walked along the
path in the direction the Indians had taken.


A little reflection, however, convinced him
of the danger of this course; as it was very
probable they would soon turn and come the
same direction back-he therefore left the
path, and, after wandering through the
woods, reached the fort in safety, several
hours after his companions, who had outrun
their pursuers and returned likwise.

resistance would offer but a stronger incite-
ment to daring vice.


Whatever is sacred, or beautiful, carries
its own protection with it, and nature sur
rounds it with but slight defence, which
warns but wounds not-for with beauty,
mildness alone should be united. Thus to
innocence, nature gave modcsty blush.

full articles.headline: From Keppcrs Journey from India to Engla
full articles.article:
From Keepers Journey from india 10 England


MoRAvIAN EsTABLrsHMENT.-I went
to visit Moravian Establish mcnt in the
town of Sarapta. Opposite the Inn former
ly stood house containing eighty bachelors,
and near it one containing eighty spinsters
The house of the former has been burnt
down; and that of the latter has escaped
The females divide their own dwelling with
the men, till theirs is rebuilt. When bach
elor is tired of life Of celbacy, he goes
next door, chooses one out OF the eighty SPIN
sters, and makes her his wife. The pair be-
come members of the general community,
and keep house for themselves. The va
cancies are filled up by the children OF those
who had once been inmates OF these mansions
of single blessedness. was highly gratificd
with my visit to this human hive. Every
thing was in the neatest order; the sisters,
as they are called, with their little caps and
uniform dress, reminded me of our fair Qua
kers The female children were reading
and writing; the young women were engaged
in domestic employ ments. The old maids,
were occupied in knitting and needle
work. All were busy at the occupation
best adapted to their peculiar habits and
talents Nor were the brothers idle; here
were shoemakers, tailors, weavers, printers
and book binders. / was shown tne col
lection of the serpents and other reptiles OF
Southern Russia. saw also large coilec-
ton of antiquities found in the neighborhood'
which proves the former existence OF an an
cient city ON this spot


Curious ExHIBITIoN.-On entering
Nnana. we were witnesses to rather Gu
rious exhibition. / should first mention, that
the Persians are in the habit OF sleeping on
f1at roofs of their houses, during the sum-
.mer months. Day was just breaking as we
arrived. AS the houses of the poor classes
are generally not more than eight feet high,

full articles.headline:
From the Kentucky Gazette.
NOTES OFT KENTUCKY.
full articles.article:
In the month of August 1886, Mr.. Francis
Downing then lad lived in fort, where
soon afterwards, an Ironworks was erected
by Mr.. Jacob Myers, which is known as
the Slate cpeek works. and owned by Col.
Thomas Dye Owings. 4


One morning young man by the name OF
Yates, together with Mr.. Downing, went out
in search q horse that had strayed away
from the fort. After travelling six or eight
miles in search of the horse, Downing be-
gan 10 be alarmed at the idea of danger
from Indians, and observed to Yates, (who
was much older than himself, and to whom
he locked Up for protection) that he thought
he heard noise like sticks cracking behind
them, Yates laughed at him anc told him
not to be a coward--tMat it was oHly his I'M
agnetiun, and that there was no danger
whatever. Downing, however, was not
convinced, but embraced the first favorable
opportunity tIfordcd him for conccalnent,
to step in a thick cluster Of whortclberry
bushes, while Yates went on. ln few
minutes an Indian was seen by Downing,
running towards him, until he was within a
bout one hundred yards, when he suddenly
stopped. Downing to use his own express
| ion, was as it were, Mtnder&trnck. He re-
solved however, as he had gun, to fire and
run, but unfortunately his gun having
double trigger, before he raised her to his
face, she went off, and, as he remarks, ne IN
stantly 7vent oftoo! After running some
distance, he met Yates, who having heard
the report of the gun, had turned to ascer-
tain what was the matter, and learning that
thev were closely pursued by Indians, they
ran together At length they reached de-
clivity, and we're compelled, in following the
path, to de scend into valley surrounded by
VILLA Iar fhav Indians. who
| had taken shorter route, and were running
| by another route towards the bottom OF the
! v lley There was no alternative; It was
absolutely necessary to keep the path and
to run with the utmost possible rapidity, al
though from the superior knowledge possess
ed by the Indians ofdfferent roads. they had
gained considerably on the pursued, and
seemed likely soon to overtake them. Both
parties ran on until they reached dry gut
ter in the middle of the valley. about six
feet deep, and Of considerable width. The
| Indians had, by this time approached very
near them, and attempted to leap across the
gutter at about the same time With the
whites. All got across safe except Mt u.
who Just reached the edge OF the gutter, "a
gainst which striking his foot, he fell upon
his breas, rebounded and fell backwards in-
to the gutter. The violence OF the fail al
most deprived him Of breath tor time, but
fortunately the Indians were too intent upon
the chase to observe his remaining behind,
and both happening to direct their attention
solely to MIR. Yates, continued to pursue
hin. Mr.. Downing at length recovering
from the shock, walked along IN the gutter,
which grew shalower as he advanced, and
soon ceased to serve the purpose OF conceal
ing him from the sight OF the lniians. At
length he discovered one of them returning
in search of him he instantly dropped his
gun. left the gutter, and ran back the same


wav he had come.--The injury he had re-
ceived from his fall, affected his speed, and
the Inlian gained upon him rapidly. After
running a considerable distance, considering
his case a desperate ono, and his being over
taken inevitable, he came to large poplar


tree, which had been blown down by. the


wind, II so happened that wh'lstHhe ran a.
long one side of the tree, the lndian pursued


him on the other. At this critical momcnt,


he felt himself caught by the leg, ana was


compelled to make momentary pause,


when he perceived that he had been stop"


ped by a small dog, which instantly ran q


way from him. This pause mac gwen 10
the Indian considerable advantage, and he


percejyed himself likely TO be caught at


the root of the tree. Mos' fortunately how


ever lust at that spot, a large she bear had


taken up her abode with several cubs. Not


being pleased with the violence with Which


the Indian approached her young, she IN


stantly attacked him, when Mr. Downing,
taking advantage of the interference OF TINS
unexpected coadjutor, suddenly wheeled
around, and left the savage engaged IN


most violent struggle with his new adversa-
nv. What was the result of the rencounter,


we are not informed. 1t had, however, the
happy effect of preserving Mr.. Downing
from almost inevitable destruction; and as
no remains of the Indian was ever alter


wards found, at or near the place, it is prop


able he escaped with his life, it not without
considerable injury.


Mr.. Yates likewise succeeded in getting
off unhurt. After running several miles, he
concealed himself amidst trees or in Cane
Drake, and he thus eluded the pursuit, and


returned home safe.


1t was custom with Mr. Downing, i'll the


summer, about the time referred to above,


to go out of the fort every afternoon, to


cluster OF hickory trees, several hundrea


yards distant, for the purpose OF shooting


squirrels, which at that place were very hu


merous.-Near his path, (as he afterwards


s:scovered) fifteen Indians lay concealed tor
three davs, behind large log, where they


had placed a number of bushes to serve as a
blind. there waiting for a favorable oppor-


tuntv to kill some one or more men, and Oh
tain y,luuder

full articles.headline: AIAXIAIS.
full articles.article:
"Do not despise poor man because he is
such: the lion is not less noble because he Is
chained.'


ga lady's face, like a coat in the tale of tub,
il left alone, will wear well, but if you load it
with foreign ornaments, you destroy the original
ground"


"lngratitude is a crime SO shameful, that the
man was never yet found, who would acknowl-
edge himself guilty Of it."


"ro mourn without measure is folly--not to
mourn at all, insensbty."


"The coin that is most current among mankind,
is hattery the only benefit of which is, that by
hearing what we are not, VIC may be instructed
what we ought to be-"


"The wise man, applauds him whom he thinks
most yirtuous; the rest of the world, him who is
most wealthy"


"There is mean in all things. Even virtue
itself hath its stated limits which not being strict
iy observed il ceases to be virtue"
'By taking revenge a man is but even with
bis enemy; but in passing it over he is superior"
"Religion is the best shield, but the worst
cloak in the world"


at is to ofectatioa the world owes its whole
race Of coxcombs Nature in her whole drama
never drew such part. She has sometimes
made fool, but a coxcomb is always of his own
making.''


"Sylla's monument had this inscription: No
friend ever overcame me with Kindness, no enc
my with injury


Dogenes the cynic being asked which kind
Of wine was the best, answered, ''that which we
drink at other peoples expense"
There is perhaps nothing more bitter in the
lot of poverty than the distance to which it
throws man from the woman he loves


AMBITION.
Ambitions monstrous stomach does increase
ny eating; and it fears to starve unless
1t still may feed and all it sees devour.
Ambition is not tir'd with toll, nor cloy'd with


pow'r.


FRIEND.


True happiness
consists not in the multitude of friends,
hut in the worth and choce nor would have
virtue popular regard pursue;
